#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Find a Pet
#Text=The physical and emotional health benefits of living with a pet are well-documented : relaxation , decreased blood pressure , companionship and many others .
#Text=Many households consider their pets to be family members .
#Text=Finding the right pet requires careful consideration , for your sake and for that of the pet .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Confirm that all members of the family agree on the decision to buy or adopt a pet .
#Text=Adding a pet to the family involves a commitment of years or even decades .
#Text=Talk with a doctor before you adopt or buy a pet if any family members have allergies .
#Text=Evaluate your lifestyle and determine the amount of daily care you are willing and able to devote to the pet .
#Text=Consider the ages and activity levels of family members .
#Text=Dogs will require walking and exercise , training , feeding and grooming .
#Text=Fish need other types of maintenance , such as aquarium cleaning and careful attention to temperature .
#Text=Each type of pet will have unique needs to be considered .
#Text=Consider financial and other limitations .
#Text=Research typical veterinary , food , grooming and other expenses , which are generally far more than the initial cost of buying a pet or adopting one from a rescue group .
#Text=If you do not own your home or apartment , be sure that your landlord allows pets .
#Text=Think about whether you are likely to move to a place in the future that may not allow pets .
#Text=Learn about the type of pet you are considering .
#Text=Talk with other pet owners , read about pet care , visit pet adoption clinics and dog shows , cat shows or 4H shows .
#Text=Decide whether you will purchase or adopt a pet and where the pet will come from .

#Text=If you know , for example , that you want a small dog , you may find a pet through the local shelter or humane society , through an Internet search of national pet-adoption agencies or through a breed-specific rescue group or a breeder .
#Text=A good breeder or rescue group is concerned about the welfare of the animal and of the family and will work to make sure that you adopt or buy a pet that is a good match .
#Text=Find one that will accept the return of the animal if the placement or purchase is not successful for unforeseen reasons .
#Text=Prepare your home and family for the pet .
#Text=Obtain items such as food and water dishes , a cage , pet beds and toys , an aquarium and filters or whatever supplies are needed .
#Text=Have these items on hand before you buy or adopt a pet .
#Text=Clarify what the responsibilities and schedules of all members of the household will be after you find a pet , such as feeding , litter box cleaning and dog walking .
#Text=Find and speak with a veterinarian who is experienced in caring for the type of pet you plan to get .
#Text=Tell the vet that you are trying to find a pet and ask his or her advice on sources and preparations .
#Text=Plan a visit to the vet for an initial appointment as soon as possible after you adopt or buy a pet and bring it home .
#Text=Tips
#Text=You may want to adopt a pet that is full-grown .
#Text=These pets have often been house trained , or may have lived in a foster home that will have helpful information about the individual animal .
#Text=Your rescue group or breeder may not immediately have the pet you are looking for , but will work with you to find a pet for your family .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Most animal experts advise against purchasing pets from pet shops .
#Text=Animals sold in pet shops are often from mass-breeding operations where little or no attention is paid to temperament or the long-term health of the animals being bred .
#Text=These animals frequently are less socialized than pets obtained from a humane society or breeder .
#Text=Adopt or buy a pet after careful consideration and research , not on impulse .
